long-description.p:
At The above location there are the remains of a Rubble stone windmill on a circular plinth the Exterior plaque reads "This Mill was built by Edward and Mary Walsh of Boranstown".
Now around two centuries old, it was worked as a mill by the Walsh family and was rebuilt in 1829. After that, it lay disused for many many years, The mill is only one of around 100 windmills known to have been worked in the then grain-rich county.
On a clear day its said the nine of the counties of Ireland came be seen from the trig point beside the mill

p.font:
To walk to the cache you will need to cross a private field.
Please do not open the gate there are stone steps built into the wall please stay on the public track up to the Mill.
Take care when there is livestock in the fields please do not attempt this cache if you are not comfortable with large animals

long-description.p: To find the cache you need to visit the above location and take note of the year this Windmill was built call this A.B.C.D
Also take note of the number of slit windows there are call this number E
The Cache is at N53 CC.D(B+E)A W6 EC.DC(C+D)

ul.li:
2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by Serapis
Great 360 degree views from the windmill. Nearly missed the inscription. A few curious sheep were wandering around. Found the cache quickly with very accurate co-ords. New log sheet noted. Thanks for the cache.

2010-03-21T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Mullingar Man
DNF, seems to happen a lot in meath

2010-03-21T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Soupcooler
Failed to get year the mill was built anywhere on the ruin so had to give up!

2009-12-13T20:00:00Z : Found it by Spark_ie
Quick grab while on tour in Louth/Meath today, with Donnacha. Had to dodge a muggle at the cache site, but he seemed more interested in feeding his horses across the road !! [:D] TFTC, Spark_ie

2009-12-13T20:00:00Z : Found it by Donnacha
Found with Spark_ie while on a tour of Winsocker land. Thanks for the cache.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Windmolen
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
At The above location there are the remains of a Rubble stone windmill on a circular plinth the Exterior plaque reads "This Mill was built by Edward and Mary Walsh of Boranstown".
Now around two centuries old, it was worked as a mill by the Walsh family and was rebuilt in 1829. After that, it lay disused for many many years, The mill is only one of around 100 windmills known to have been worked in the then grain-rich county.

On a clear day its said the nine of the counties of Ireland came be seen from the trig point beside the mill

The Cache

To walk to the cache you will need to cross a private field.
Please do not open the gate there are stone steps built into the wall please stay on the public track up to the Mill.
Take care when there is livestock in the fields please do not attempt this cache if you are not comfortable with large animals

Stage One

To find the cache you need to visit the above location and take note of the year this Windmill was built call this A.B.C.D

Also take note of the number of slit windows there are call this number E

Final Location

The Cache is at N53 CC.D(B+E)A W6 EC.DC(C+D)


The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

FN13KM0 - Final
N/S __ 째 __ . ___ W/E ___ 째 __ . ___
